ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A good exposure to current work in the field of fairness in ML.
Different perspectives on ensuring equality in AI and ML algorithms.
I learned: the basics of reading mathematical definitions key definitions and concepts surrounding algorithmic fairness

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The small class size meant that there were many opportunities to ask questions and receive feedback. Possibly adding an additional blog-post assignment in the first half of the semester would lead to higher engagement early on (since the class met only once a week).

Definitions and concepts were very clear. Expectations were sometimes a little unclear sometimes, but this might have been because the students in the class had different backgrounds and different skill levels. Sometimes it felt like the course outcomes were very introductory, and at other times it felt like we were supposed to have a pretty extensive knowledge of the underlying mathematics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Students interested in doing research in the fair ML field should definitely take the course, as should all CS/S&DS graduate students who want to better understand the societal and ethical implications of their work.

Yes, I think this course should probably be a requirement for students who focus in statistics or computer science. Much of the content is incredibly important with consideration to bias that arises with machine learning and data.
